facts.text: Trial court dismissed the plaintiffs' suit for partition and separate possession of their half share in a house and mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: ment of the Patna High Court reversing that of the trial companyrt dismissing the plaintiffs suit for partition and separate possession of their half share in a house and for payment of companypensation

facts.text: Property purchased jointly by Juri Mal, Gajanand, Ramasahai Sah, Jahuri Sah and Ramgali Sah on June 26, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number disputed before us are these The property in dispute which is situate within the limits of the municipality of Bhagalpur was purchased jointly by five persons, Juri Mal, Gajanand, Ramasahai Sah, Jahuri Sah and Ramgali Sah. The first two of these are father and son  and were members of a joint Hindu family .

facts.text: Juri Mal and Gajanand were father and son, members of a joint Hindu family, both dead.

anchor.surface_text: The first two of these are father and son  and were members of a joint Hindu family . Both of them are dead. Plaintiffs 1 to 4 are the sons and plaintiff 6 is the widow of Gajanand and plaintiff No. 5 is the widow of Jurimal.

facts.text: Plaintiffs 1 to 4 are sons of Gajanand, plaintiff 6 widow of Gajanand, plaintiff 5 widow of Jurimal.

anchor.surface_text: Both of them are dead. Plaintiffs 1 to 4 are the sons and plaintiff 6 is the widow of Gajanand and plaintiff No. 5 is the widow of Jurimal. Jurimal, Gajanand  companystituted a joint Hindu family  and plaintiffs 1 to 4 companystituted a joint Hindu family.

facts.text: Ramsahai Sah, Jahuri Sah and Ramgali Sah were brothers, members of joint Hindu family; Jahuri Sah defendant No.1, Ramgali Sah defendant No.2, karta Jahuri Sah.

anchor.surface_text: Ramsahai, Jahauri Sah and Ramgali were brothers and were members of a joint Hindu family. Jahuri Sah is defendant No. and Ramgali Sah is defendant No. 2. They, along with the remaining defendants, are members of a joint Hindu family of which Jahauri Sah is the karta.

facts.text: Two joint families purchased property, each having half interest.

anchor.surface_text: The property in question was purchased by the two joint families, each family having half interest therein. The date of the transaction was June 26, 1942.

facts.text: At purchase, property in possession of Mohanlal Marwari as tenant, evicted by court decree.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the purchase of the property it was in the possession of Mohanlal Marwari as a tenant. He was evicted therefrom by a decree of the companyrt and hereafter it was let out to Government,

facts.text: Property let out to Government at Rs. 100 per mensem, Government vacated after some time.

anchor.surface_text: He was evicted therefrom by a decree of the companyrt and hereafter it was let out to Government, the companypensation having been settled at Rs. 100/- per mensem. The Government vacated he house after some time whereafter the defendants occupied

facts.text: Defendants occupied the house except portion occupied by Isri Sah and Shib Charan Sah as tenants paying Rs. 30 monthly rent, half realised by each family.

anchor.surface_text: The Government vacated he house after some time whereafter the defendants occupied the 120 a  house excepting a portion thereof which was in the occupation of Isri Sah and Shib Charan Sah as tenants paying a monthly rent of Rs. 30 Half of this rent was being realised by each family.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claim defendants agreed to pay Rs. 200 per mensem as compensation for plaintiffs' half share upon entering possession, but did not pay.

anchor.surface_text: According to the plaintiffs when the defendants entered into possession of the property they agreed to pay Rs. 200/- per mensem as companypensation to the plaintiffs family with respect to their half share in the property. They, however, did number pay any companypensation to the plaintiffs despite the agreement.

facts.text: Suit instituted for partition, separate possession of half share, compensation from May 2, 1947 to September 11, 1951 at Rs. 200 p.m. with interest, and from suit date till possession.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing the plaintiffs suit for partition and separate possession of their half share in a house and for payment of companypensation from May 2, 1947 to September 11, 1951 at the rate of Rs. 200/p.m. with interest and for payment of companypensation

facts.text: Plaint stated Gajanand had son Shankarlal given in adoption to Sreelal, not joined as party.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint they stated that Gajanand had another son named Shankarlal but he was given in adoption to Sreelal, W. 6 and he was, therefore, number joined as party to the suit.

facts.text: Defendants claimed suit barred by Bihar Buildings Lease, Rent and Eviction Control Act, 1947, estoppel, contract was Rs. 50 p.m. not Rs. 200, time-barred for over 3 years prior.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants denied the claim and -stated that the suit was barred by the provisions of the Bihar Buildings  Lease, Rent and Eviction  Control Act, 1947  Bihar Act 3 of 1947   hereafter referred to as the Act  as well as by the rule of estopping. They also raised the plea that under the companytract entered into between the two families Rs. 501- p.m. was payable as companypensation and number Rs. 200/- p.m. as alleged by the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Trial court held Act applies, no entitlement to eviction or compensation decree, adoption not proved, suit not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that the provisions of the Act applied and by virtue of those provisions the plaintiffs were number entitled to a decree for eviction of the defendants number were they entitled to a decree for, companypensation and that the adoption of Shankarlal number having been proved the suit as companystituted was number maintainable.

facts.text: High Court held Act does not apply, adoption not specifically denied so deemed admitted, suit maintainable, contract for Rs. 200 p.m. established, mesne limited to 3 years prior to suit, interest at 6%, decreed partition and arrears.

anchor.surface_text: On this point, the High Court arrived at different companyclu- sions. The view, taken by the High Court was that the provisions of the Act did number apply to this cage, that the defendants number having specifically denied the fact of adoption and numberissues thereon having been raised the trial companyrt erred in holding that the adoption was number proved and that number-joinder of Shankarlal was number an impediment to the institution of the suit.

facts.text: Plaintiffs applied to High Court under s.151 r/w O.XX r.18 CPC for mesne profits from suit date till possession; High Court allowed till possession or 3 years from decree.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs then moved the High Court under s. 151 read with O.XX, r. 18, Code of Civil Procedure for granting them appropriate relief with respect to their claim for companypensation, for use and occupation of the house from the date of suit till delivery of possession of their share after passing the final decree.

facts.text: Supreme Court held facts not disputed include purchase, families, possession history up to rent sharing.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number disputed before us are these The property in dispute which is situate within the limits of the municipality of Bhagalpur was purchased jointly by five persons... Half of this rent was being realised by each family.

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed High Court right that Act inapplicable as parties co-owners, no landlord-tenant relation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was right in holding that the Act is inapplicable to this case. The plaintiffs and defendants were admittedly companyowners of the property. As the property had number been partitioned it was open to either or both the parties to occupy it.

facts.text: Defendants agreed to pay compensation but contended Rs. 50 p.m., not Rs. 200; High Court accepted Rs. 200, not challenged in SC.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants did number dispute that there was an agreement about payment of companypensation between the parties but their plea was that the amount agreed to was Rs. 501- p.m. and number Rs. 200/- p.m. Their companytention in this behalf was rejected by the High Court which accepted the plaintiffs companytention that the amount was Rs. 200/- p.m.

facts.text: Shankarlal adoption not specifically denied by defendants in written statement, deemed admitted under O.VIII r.5 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out that the plaintiffs have clearly stated in para 1 of the plaint that Shankarlal had been, given in adoption to Sreelal. In neither of the two written statements filed on behalf of the defendants has this assertion of fact by the plaintiffs been specifically denied.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the Bihar Buildings (Lease, Rent and Eviction) Control Act, 1947 is inapplicable to this case as the parties are co-owners with no landlord-tenant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was right in holding that the Act is inapplicable to this case. The plaintiffs and defendants were admittedly coowners of the property. As the property had not been partitioned it was open to either or both the parties to occupy it. The defendants occupied the property except a small portion which was in possession of the tenants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Co-owners hold as tenants-in-common entitled to possession of whole; exclusive occupation or agreement to pay compensation does not create landlord-tenant relationship required for Act's s.11(2) jurisdiction ouster.

holdings.text: The suit for partition is maintainable despite non-joinder of Shankarlal as his adoption was not specifically denied and is deemed admitted under O.VIII r.5 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out that the plaintiffs have clearly stated in para 1 of the plaint that Shankarlal had been, given in adoption to Sreelal. In neither of the two written statements filed on behalf of the defendants has this assertion of fact by the plaintiffs been specifically denied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No specific denial or issue raised; denial of knowledge not sufficient under O.VIII r.5; prima facie evidence from witness sufficient; oral evidence admissible without deed.

holdings.text: The contract for payment of compensation (mesne profits) by occupying co-owners to non-occupying co-owners is enforceable even without ouster.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Co-owners competent to contract on enjoyment terms; no legal principle requires ouster as sine qua non for compensation liability; distinguishes general rule from contractual arrangements.

holdings.text: Agreement to pay compensation between co-owners does not create landlord-tenant relationship bringing the case under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that the defendants agreed to pay compensation to the plaintiffs for their occupation of the entire property  ignoring the portion in possession of the tenants  would not bring into existence a relationship of landlord and tenant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties did not intend L-T relation; reinforces tenants-in-common doctrine.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellants' contentions on maintainability of suit and enforceability of compensation contract rejected; High Court decree for partition, separate possession and compensation upheld

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was right in holding that the Act is inapplicable to this case. The plaintiffs and defendants were admittedly coowners of the property. As the property had not been partitioned it was open to either or both the parties to occupy it. The defendants occupied the property except a small portion which was in possession of the tenants.
